rows.title: What does the 'static' keyword do in a class?
How can I make Bootstrap columns all the same height?
How to use java.util.Scanner to correctly read user input from System.in and act on it?
How do I add a delay in a JavaScript loop?
How to add to the PYTHONPATH in Windows, so it finds my modules/packages?

601: <p><strong>Just append</strong> your installation path (ex. <strong>C:\Python27\</strong>) to the <strong>PATH</strong> variable in <strong>System variables</strong>. Then close and open your <strong>command line and type 'python'</strong>.</p>

<p>You need to add to your <strong>PYTHONPATH</strong> variable instead of Windows <strong>PATH</strong> variable.</p>

<p><a href="http://docs.python.org/using/windows.html" rel="noreferrer">http://docs.python.org/using/windows.html</a></p>

<p>You can also add a <code>.pth</code> file containing the desired directory in either your <code>c:\PythonX.X</code> folder, or your <code>\site-packages folder</code>, which tends to be my preferred method when I'm developing a Python package.</p>

<p>See <a href="http://bob.ippoli.to/archives/2005/02/06/using-pth-files-for-python-development/">here</a> for more information.</p>

<p>The python 2.X paths can be set from few of the above instructions.
Python 3 by default will be installed in 
C:\Users\\AppData\Local\Programs\Python\Python35-32\
So this path has to be added to Path variable in windows environment.</p>

<p>To augment PYTHONPATH, run regedit and navigate to KEY_LOCAL_MACHINE
\SOFTWARE\Python\PythonCore and then select the folder for the python
version you wish to use. Inside this is a folder labelled PythonPath,
with one entry that specifies the paths where the default install
stores modules. Right-click on PythonPath and choose to create a new
key. You may want to name the key after the project whose module
locations it will specify; this way, you can easily compartmentalize
and track your path modifications.</p>

<p>thanks</p>

<p>For anyone trying to achieve this with Python 3.3+, the Windows installer now includes an option to add python.exe to the system search path. Read more in <a href="http://docs.python.org/3.3/using/windows.html#finding-the-python-executable" rel="nofollow">the docs</a>.</p>

<p>While this question is about the 'real' Python, it did come up in a websearch for 'Iron Python PYTHONPATH'. For Iron Python users as confused as I was: It turns out that Iron Python looks for an environment variable called <code>IRONPYTHONPATH</code>.</p>

<p>Linux/Mac/POSIX users: Don't forget that not only does Windows use <code>\</code> as path separators, but it also uses <code>;</code> as path delimiters, not <code>:</code>.</p>

<p>To make sure Python can find code based on the directory you are executing this code from, if not already there, add to your system environment variable: key <code>PYTHONPATH</code>, value <code>.</code>.</p>
604: <p>You only show one row so your use case may be limited to just that.  Just in case you have multiple rows, this plugin - <a href="https://github.com/Sam152/Javascript-Grids">github Javascript-grids</a> - works perfectly!  It makes each panel expand to the tallest panel, giving each row potentially a different height based on the tallest panel in that row. It's a jquery solution vs. css, but wanted to recommend it as an alternative approach.</p>
<p>I know I'm very late but now you can use the "min-height" style attribute to achieve your purpose.</p>
605: <p>This discussion has so far ignored classloader considerations. Strictly speaking, Java static fields are shared between all instances of a class for a given <strong>classloader</strong>.</p>

<p>A field can be assigned to either the class or an instance of a class. By default fields are instance variables. By using <code>static</code> the field becomes a class variable, thus there is one and only one <code>clock</code>. If you make a changes in one place, it's visible everywhere. Instance varables are changed independently of one another.</p>

<p>static methods don't use any instance variables of the class they are defined in.  A very good explanation of the difference can be found on <a href="http://leepoint.net/notes-java/flow/methods/50static-methods.html" rel="noreferrer">this page</a></p>
<p>Can also think of static members not having a "this" pointer. They are shared among all instances.</p>
